question: When did World War II end in Europe?
explanation: World War II in Europe officially ended on May 8, 1945, with Germany’s unconditional surrender.

question: Who was the first Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany?
explanation: Konrad Adenauer served as the first Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany from 1949 to 1963.

question: Which ancient civilization built the Pyramids of Giza?
explanation: The Pyramids of Giza were constructed by the ancient Egyptians and are among the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

question: When did the Berlin Wall fall?
explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, paving the way for German reunification.

question: Who was the legendary founder of Rome?
explanation: According to Roman legend, Rome was founded by Romulus in 753 BC.

question: Who was the first President of the United States of America?
explanation: George Washington served as the first U.S. President from 1789 to 1797.

question: Which Macedonian ruler conquered an empire stretching to India?
explanation: Alexander the Great (356–323 BC) expanded the Macedonian Empire across Western Asia and into Northwest India.

question: Which empire fell in AD 476?
explanation: AD 476 traditionally marks the end of the Western Roman Empire, when the last emperor, Romulus Augustulus, was deposed.

question: Which Carthaginian general crossed the Alps with elephants?
explanation: Hannibal Barca led his forces, including war elephants, across the Alps during the Second Punic War (218–201 BC).

question: Which region did Christopher Columbus officially reach in 1492?
explanation: Although Columbus believed he had found a new route to Asia, he landed on an island in the Bahamas, in what is now known as the Americas.

question: When did World War I begin?
explanation: World War I started on July 28, 1914, when Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia.

question: In which year did Martin Luther publish his 95 Theses?
explanation: On October 31, 1517, Martin Luther is said to have posted his 95 Theses on the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg.

question: When was Germany officially reunified?
explanation: Germany was officially reunified on October 3, 1990, when the German Democratic Republic (East Germany) joined the Federal Republic of Germany.

question: Which continent was extensively colonized by European powers in the 19th century?
explanation: The 19th century saw the ‘Scramble for Africa,’ during which many European states established colonies.

question: Which English king had a total of six wives?
explanation: Henry VIII (1491–1547) also initiated England’s break from the Roman Catholic Church.

question: Who was both Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain?
explanation: Charles V (1500–1558) ruled over an empire on which ‘the sun never set,’ due to Spain’s colonies in the New World.

question: To which people did Charlemagne (Karl der Große) belong?
explanation: Charlemagne (747–814) was King of the Franks and later became Emperor of the Romans (800–814).

question: Which explorer led the first circumnavigation of the world (1519–1522)?
explanation: Magellan launched the expedition in 1519; after his death, Juan Sebastián Elcano completed the circumnavigation.

question: Which Paris fortress was stormed on July 14, 1789, marking the beginning of the French Revolution?
explanation: The storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, is considered a symbolic start to the French Revolution.

question: Which Ottoman Sultan, known as 'the Magnificent,' elevated the empire to its peak of power?
explanation: Suleiman the Magnificent (1494–1566) expanded the Ottoman Empire and oversaw its golden age.

question: What was Germany called between 1871 and 1918?
explanation: After its founding in 1871, it was known as the German Empire until Emperor Wilhelm II abdicated in 1918.

question: Which Viking is believed to have reached parts of North America around AD 1000?
explanation: Leif Erikson is said to have landed in regions of modern-day Newfoundland (Canada) around the year 1000.

question: Which dynasty ruled Russia from 1613 to 1917?
explanation: The Romanovs were the last imperial dynasty of Russia, ending with the abdication of Tsar Nicholas II in 1917.

question: Who is considered the father of the Indian independence movement, known for nonviolent resistance?
explanation: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (called Mahatma) led India to independence (1947) through nonviolent civil disobedience.

question: Which 1215 document limited the powers of the English king?
explanation: Magna Carta, recognized by King John in 1215, is a key early legal document restricting royal authority.

question: Which German ruler, nicknamed 'the Great,' founded the Ottonian Empire?
explanation: Otto I (912–973) was the first Holy Roman Emperor of the Ottonian dynasty.

question: Who was the first German Emperor of the so-called Second Reich?
explanation: Wilhelm I (1797–1888) was proclaimed German Emperor in 1871 and reigned until 1888.

question: In about which century did the Industrial Revolution begin in Great Britain?
explanation: The Industrial Revolution started in England around 1760 and spread across Europe in the 19th century.

question: Who reached India by sailing around the Cape of Good Hope in 1498?
explanation: In 1498, Vasco da Gama arrived in Calicut (Kozhikode), opening a sea route to Asia for Portugal.

question: Which peace treaty ended the Thirty Years’ War in 1648?
explanation: The Peace of Westphalia of 1648 ended the Thirty Years’ War, reshaping the European state system.

question: Who was the founder of the Mongol Empire?
explanation: Genghis Khan (1162–1227) united the Mongol tribes and created the largest contiguous empire in history.

question: Which Chinese dynasty reigned during Marco Polo’s visit around 1300?
explanation: The Yuan Dynasty (1279–1368), established by the Mongols, was in power when Marco Polo traveled in China.

question: Which pharaoh became famous when his nearly intact tomb was discovered in 1922?
explanation: Tutankhamun’s tomb was found in 1922 by Howard Carter in the Valley of the Kings.

question: Which Byzantine emperor created the 'Codex' (a collection of laws) in the 6th century AD?
explanation: Emperor Justinian I (482–565) compiled the 'Codex Justinianus,' preserving Roman legal traditions.

question: Which naval battle took place in 202 BC and sealed Rome’s victory over Carthage?
explanation: The Battle of Zama (202 BC) resulted in a decisive Roman victory over Hannibal and Carthage.

question: Who was the first Roman Emperor?
explanation: Augustus (31 BC–AD 14) established the Principate and is considered the first Roman Emperor.

question: Which Polish scholar laid the groundwork for the heliocentric model in the early modern period?
explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus (1473–1543) argued in his work that the Earth orbits the Sun.

question: When did the Meiji Restoration, which modernized Japan, begin?
explanation: The Meiji Restoration began in 1868 and initiated a rapid modernization and industrialization of Japan.

question: Which Emperor of Ethiopia addressed the League of Nations in 1936 to protest the Italian invasion?
explanation: Haile Selassie I appealed to the League of Nations in 1936 against Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia.

question: What is the name of the conflict between Emperor and Pope (1075–1122) over the right to appoint bishops?
explanation: The Investiture Controversy ended in 1122 with the Concordat of Worms, clarifying the appointment of clerical offices.

question: Who is considered the founder of the Ottoman Empire around 1300?
explanation: Osman I (1258–1326) is regarded as the namesake and founder of the Ottoman dynasty.

question: Who wrote the political treatise 'The Prince' (Il Principe) around 1513?
explanation: Machiavelli’s 'Il Principe' is one of the most influential works of Renaissance political philosophy.

question: Which Aztec ruler encountered the Spanish conquistadors under Hernán Cortés in 1519?
explanation: Moctezuma II (1466–1520) was captured by the Spanish and died during the siege of Tenochtitlán.

question: When did the Great Plague (Black Death) spread across Europe?
explanation: Between 1347 and 1351, the Black Death killed roughly one-third of Europe’s population.

question: Who founded the Jesuit Order in the 16th century?
explanation: Ignatius of Loyola (1491–1556) established the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) in 1534.

question: In which battle did William the Conqueror seize England in 1066?
explanation: William the Conqueror defeated the Anglo-Saxons at the Battle of Hastings, becoming King of England.

question: Which agreement was signed in 1494 to divide the New World between Spain and Portugal?
explanation: Under the Treaty of Tordesillas (1494), Spain and Portugal split the non-European world between them.

question: Which Persian king began building the ceremonial capital Persepolis around 518 BC?
explanation: Darius I started construction on Persepolis, later expanded under Xerxes I.

question: Which Mesopotamian civilization invented cuneiform, one of the oldest known writing systems?
explanation: The Sumerians developed cuneiform in the 4th millennium BC, later adopted by other Mesopotamian peoples.
